rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Carmen is incredible! 255 isn't a required course for Spanish minor but take it to keep up  Spanish! She will MAKE SURE you understand concepts. And there's not much work If you aren't the best at understanding Spanish, it may be slightly difficult to understand her, but she's great.  She brings you candy almost every day (like Lindt Truffles)

One of my favorite professors at UNC.  Professor Hsu enjoyed the subject she was teaching and she was able to get us interested in it too.  The class was mainly discussion based and the readings weren't too bad.  Prof. Hsu was very helpful and she was easy to contact and approach for help when needed.

The best Spanish professor I've had.  Her lectures are engaging and fairly often hilarious.  She's super nice (brings candy to every test!) and exceedingly helpful during office hours.  She makes medieval/Golden Age Spain absolutely fascinating, and I feel like I've learned so much!  Absolutely recommended.
She is very interested in teaching and tries hard to make sure the class understands everything. She is very energetic and helpful, and has a good sense of humor.
No Comments
Really fun teacher to take. Very helpful and makes Spanish learning very fun...

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: The quizzes are more like tests and he's a bit of a stickler for detail. He's a little hard to get a read on, one minute he'll be laughing and joking and the next he'll be summoning you to his office to tell you you don't talk enough in class.

Emilio is such a nice guy. He's very laid back, but he expects you to take the class seriously. He calls on people who don't raise their hands, so be sure to do the reading. He's really cool and has a great relationship with his students.
Great class, awesome professor, I would highly recommend.

My best suggestion is to simply agree with whatever he says and do not disagree with anything. Any original thought or opinion that is not in agreement with his will be overruled and be misconstrued as you not properly understanding the text. His grading and expectations are unclear and he is rarely prepared for class.
Laid-back, friendly dude who definitely keeps things interesting.  Not a class for people who want to just slide by, but great for anyone who wants a different perspective.  He's a lot of fun.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Not many tests, a few quizzes and quite a few essays
One of two professors that I had for a Global Art Cinema Class. Very funny, understands what he is talking about, and can effectively communicate with people who are new to the subject of film.

This guy is really friendly and funny, and I enjoyed his lectures. HOWEVER, be aware: I hated this class. The class starts with a thirty minute lecture, followed by a movie. "Oh! a movie? It can't be that bad!" But it is. I enjoyed about half of the movies we watched, and most were around two hours long. For 3 credit hours, this class isnt worth it

Excellent teacher and absolutely hilarious! Attendance and participation matter, and classes are reading intensive, so if you're not willing to come prepared for class or not willing to learn anything, don't take this teacher. Classes are also fairly writing intensive, but not unbearably. He's good at not bashing a dumb comment, but NO SLACKERS!
Terrible correcting essays.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Estrada was an incredible teacher for this freshman seminar. He was so knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, and that motivated me to become more involved as well. He's hilarious and super helpful! I hope to take more classes with him because of how patient, encouraging and approachable he is. Definitely take him if you can!
One of my favorite coursesprofessors to date! So nice and relatable and just an all around nice guy ! Extremely helpful and easy to understand! I would recommend him to anyone!
I was worried about this class initially but he made it so much easier than what I had heard from other people with other professors. Strongly recommend!
He is the best professor I have EVER had. He is GREAT at keeping you interested in the material, always very helpful, extremely passionate, you will fall in love with him! :)
He is an amazing teacher!!! I am horrible at spanish and am doing really well in his class.. take during summer session and pay attention to all the details on the coutries. Fantastico!
No Comments

Very passionate professor, made me much more interested in the material. I felt that the class tries to cover too much, but that isn't entirely his fault. He is very helpful and explains things clearly, always open to help at office hours. Great guy!

His enthusiasm was contagious--a real passion for Latin American literature; however, I didn't take the class very seriously because it's so much easier than some of the other Spanish literature professors. If you're a Spanish major and take this class and don't make an "A" you need to find a new major.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This was a surprisingly entertaining seminar. I learned a lot where I didn't expect to. The grading and work is pretty easy, it's a few essays every now and then.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I didn't really like her at all. When speaking English at times, she makes it sounds like she's more knowledgeable than you. She takes forever to hand back grades and is a very disorganized professor. The class in general can be easy, but she was a bit too much for me.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: As long as you come to class and do the assignments, you'll be good to go. It was Tu/Th so Tuesdays we had discussions (just participate once for credit) then Thursdays were presentations (each student presents twice throughout the semester). Only one 2-paragraph paper due each week and he gave A's out like candy. Definitely take his class.

Probably one of the most boring classes I have ever taken. Dominguez is a really nice guy, but seems to think everyone in the class has an extensive prior knowledge of Spain in the Middle Ages. I did poorly in the class all semester (mainly because I was bored by the material), but the final was 50% of the overall grade and was surprisingly easy.

Took SPAN 101 in the summer with him so I went everyday and he I have to say the constant repetition gets old, but he made sure everything was clear. He provided a very solid base of understanding. Only negative was that he is kinda particular on the tests but he occasionally miscounts how many points should be taken off.

The lectures were pretty dry and boring, and he posts an excessive amount of articles on Blackboard (I'm sure no one read them all - who had the time?). The class is slightly disorganized but manageable.  I didn't enjoy the course, but I have nothing but good things to say about Dominguez. Very approachable/kind/equitable. But I must say: easy A.

Dr. Dominguez rules my world!!!!  He is such an amazing person, and a great professor.  He also puts all of the readings online (for 371 as well), so no book.  His quizzes are hard, but the exams are easy. He is wonderfully easygoing and passionate about his subject matter.  I would take 20 million more classes with him if I could!

I disliked this class at first because he is boring and I couldn't read the texts, but it started to grow on me. He explains the material well, and has a grading system that basically ensures that an honest effort will get you an "A". The quizzes are hard, but the exams are easy. Really a low key, easy-going professor who cares about his students.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Please do not take this class as a first year seminar. There are 4 papers (2 worth 10% of your grade and 2 worth 40%). The average grades were 85-95 on the 10% papers, but of course the 40% midterm was graded harder. There are so many more interesting seminars that could be taken. She is very unclear, not organized and never stays on topic.

This was a great class. Professor Perelmuter is very fair. The class consists of two paper grades and two essay format exams. Professor Perelmuter tends to give out grades anywhere in the 80s to the low 90s. She also records attendance and uses that to help raise or lower your overall average. The novels we read in class were also pretty good.
Dr. Perelmuter is really nice and takes the time to meet with confused students outside of class if they are struggling.  She comes off mildly intimidating in class, but she's actually very sweet.

I met with her to figure out which classes I needed to take over the summer to graudate. She would not count one course I had taken for my major becuase she did not feel that the course was hard enough to count- even though it was listed as a course that counted. Luckily, another advisor caught her 'mistake' and fixed it.

I don't think people that have made the previous comments have gotten to know professor Perelmuter very well. She is wonderful, very resourceful and always willing to help students. She is in my thesis committee and has been one of the most helpful persons in it. She is very knowledgeable and a great scholar.

This woman was my advisor. She almost ruined my life lying about courses. She was a pisspoor advisor. She gave me advice one day and literally the next day had vacated her office without one word. I was up the creek. She didn't mention one word the day before. She's evil, avoid her!

Dr. Perelmuter, despite her Cuban background, doesn't seem to be able to communicate effectively the causes behind many problems that plague Latin America. Our class discussions, which she tried to dominate, were meaningless and trite, and completely based on conjecture. Avoid at any cost!
